note.title: The 4 questions you should stop asking during your one-on-one meetings
note.fname: dev.interview.The 4 questions you should stop asking during your one-on-one meetings

pageProps.body:
The 4 questions you should stop asking during your one-on-one meetings

https://medium.com/signal-v-noise/the-4-questions-you-should-stop-asking-during-your-one-on-one-meetings-ed7431da11aa

#1: â€œHowâ€™s it going?â€

Ah, the perennial one-on-one meeting opener. It seems like a solid way to break the ice and initiate the one-on-one meeting. Yet itâ€™s unusual that you ever get an answer other than â€œFineâ€ or â€œGoodâ€ in response. While someone might truly be fine and good in reality (which is great!)â€¦ the conversation usually stops there. Anything personal you wanted to learn, any sense of rapport you wanted to create dies with the question, â€œHowâ€™s it going?â€ This is because, as a society, the question â€œHowâ€™s it going?â€ has become our automatic greeting to each other, so our answer to it has become just as automatic.

What should you ask instead?

If youâ€™re looking for a casual, open-ended way to kick off a one-on-one, ask â€œHowâ€™s life?â€ instead. It may not seem like a big difference, but it makes a big difference. â€œHowâ€™s life?â€ gives permission for someone to talk more personally about life â€” about what they did that weekend, how their family is doing, how their personal side project is coming along, how theyâ€™re managing their workload. â€œHowâ€™s life?â€ invites the other person to elaborate. Though, quite frankly, almost any other opening question than â€œHowâ€™s it going?â€ to going to help you learn more about how someone is doing in their life.

#2: â€œWhatâ€™s the latest on __?â€

It can be tempting to use your one-on-one session as time to get caught up on whatâ€™s going on. However, keep in mind that this completely squanders the purpose of your one-on-one meeting, to begin with. A one-on-one meeting isnâ€™t a reporting session. Itâ€™s not an accountability tool. A one-on-one meeting is your radar. Itâ€™s your metal detector. Itâ€™s one of the only ways you have to unearth whatâ€™s actually going on in your team, and what an employee is thinking and feeling. You can get a list of deliverables in Slack any olâ€™ time. Client problems, unforeseen issues with the product, messy team dynamics, unspoken personal frustration â€” this is only time youâ€™ll get to hear that stuff.

Some of you may be thinking, â€œWell, Claire, asking this question has helped me get good insights into the teamâ€™s problems.â€ Yes, Iâ€™m with you. This question â€œWhatâ€™s the latest on X?â€ can be great if youâ€™re using it to segue into asking deeper questions. For example, perhaps you follow it up with, â€œWhatâ€™s most frustrating about how X has been going so far?â€ Or, â€œWhere do you feel you need more support in working on X?â€ Merely asking â€œWhatâ€™s the latest on X?â€ falls flat if you use it singularly.

What should you ask instead?

Ask something specific about the project, instead of asking for a general project update. Possibly my favorite question to ask to instead of â€œWhatâ€™s the latest on X?â€ is â€œCan you tell me about whatâ€™s been most surprising about working on X so far?â€ If an employee has found something surprising, good chances that youâ€™ll find it surprising too. A surprising insight is always useful for you to form an accurate picture of potential issues bubbling up within your team.

#3: â€œHow can I help you?â€

The intention behind this question is fantastic. You want to help, you want to get out of their way, you want to figure what you can be doing better. However, this question is the worst way to signal that. Why? Itâ€™s lazy. It makes the person receiving the question do all the hard work of having to come up with the answer. Itâ€™s also a very hard question to answer, especially on-the-spot and given that youâ€™re a person in a position of power. Youâ€™re asking a person to critique you, â€œThe Boss,â€ across all spectrums and come up with something actionable for you to do. If you do ask this question, answers tend to be, â€œNothing I can think of right now,â€ something vague, or an answer that involves something that youâ€™re already doing. Rarely do you get a precise, thoughtful to-do that youâ€™ll then go implement the next day.

What should you ask instead?

Suggest something you think you can be doing to help. Then ask, â€œWhat do you think?â€ For example: â€œI was thinking Iâ€™m being too hands-on on this project. Should I back off and check-in with you only bi-weekly? What do you think?â€ By being targeted in what you suggest â€” and suggesting it yourself â€” you make it easier for that person to share the exact ways in which you can support them. You help your employees by suggesting what you think you can do to help, first.

#4: â€œHow can we improve?â€

This is the vaguest of questions. The problem with vague questions is they invite vague answers. You prompt the person to offer broad suppositions and knee-jerk assumptions, instead of exact details and practical examples. Ask an employee â€œHow can we improve?â€ and they think, â€œHmm, from a business development perspective? Marketing perspective? Leadership perspective? Where to even begin?â€ Now, some employees you work with will be able to craft a distinct, rich answer from this question. But itâ€™s infrequent. And itâ€™s probable they spent a good chunk of time thinking about the answer ahead of time. For most employees who you ask this question to without any warning, youâ€™ll receive a variant of â€œI think things are pretty good right nowâ€ about 90% of the time.

What should you ask instead?

Focus your efforts on asking specific questions, instead of defaulting to general ones. For instance: â€œWhat do you think is the most overlooked area of the business?â€ or â€œWhere do you think weâ€™re behind in, that other companies are excelling at?â€ Notice how specific each of these questions are. The more specific the question, the more effective they are.

You may have cringed while reading this list. Many of you (including myself!) have found yourself asking all four questions, at one time or another.

No need to panic or be hard on yourself. You havenâ€™t inflicted irreparable harm to your team. Your sins are not unforgivable. Rather, I hope sharing the unintended consequences of these four questions nudge you to evaluate the questions you ask during your one-on-one meetings a little more closely.

The questions do the heavy lifting. The questions determine the path to which your one-on-one meetings will take. Ask thoughtful, sincere questions, and thereâ€™s a higher likelihood your answers returned back to you will be thoughtful and sincere too.

> I've often described my motivation for building software to others using imagery: I like to go find a secluded beach, build a large, magnificent sand castle, and then walk away. Will anyone notice? Probably not. Will the waves eventually destroy it? Yep. Did I still get immense satisfaction? Absolutely. - [aliasxneo](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=41497113)

> We love to see the process, not just the result. The imperfections in your work can be beautiful if they show your struggle for perfection, not a lack of care. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/is-perfection-boring/)

> Simplicity, even if it sacrifices some ideal functionality has better survival characteristics than the-right-thing. - [The Rise of Worse is Better](https://www.dreamsongs.com/RiseOfWorseIsBetter.html)

> [Roberto Blake was talking about making 100 crappy videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnUBaQ1Sp_E) to get better over time. Putting in the reps and improving a little bit each time.
>
> Putting in the work without expecting any external reward at first (eg views, followers, likes, etc) will pay off in the long run. - [100 Scrappy Things](https://www.florin-pop.com/blog/100-scrappy-things/)

> Make the difficult habitual, the habitual easy, and the easy beautiful. - [Constantin S. Stanislavski](https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/7102271-make-the-difficult-habitual-the-habitual-easy-and-the-easy)

> A good match is a **structured** dance, where players aim to **score** while they are following well-defined **rules**. This **freedom within a structure** is what makes it fun. - [ralphammer](https://ralphammer.com/how-to-get-started/)

- [Pivot Points](https://longform.asmartbear.com/pivot-points/)

  - non-judgmental aspects of personality that can be strengths in some contexts and weaknesses in others
  - Pivot Points are fixed in the short term

- [Hedged Bets](https://longform.asmartbear.com/predict-the-future/#hedged-bets)
  - trading slightly less maximum upside for predictable, net-positive outcomes.

> â€œMotivation often comes after starting, not before. Action produces momentum.â€

> - James Clear

> Focus is more about **not** keeping busy when you need to wait for something.  
> Eat the boredom for a minute.
>

I hate to say it, but if you're not eating a good amount of vegetables and fruit, decent protein, sleep, etc, no amount of XYZ will catch up to that detriment. - [CE02](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=35056071)
